headline: J.D. Vance in Marion: Donald Trump was a great president, MAGA movement is special
author: Andrew Carter
sentences: During a stop on Thursday morning in Marion, Vance explained how he has transitioned from a staunch "Never Trump" position during the 2016 presidential election to earning the coveted — and controversial — endorsement from Trump in his bid to become the next senator from Ohio.

... "It is time for the entire MAGA movement, the greatest in the history of our Country, to unite behind J.D.’s campaign because, unlike so many other pretenders and wannabes, he will put America First.
Vance won Trump's support over Republican Party primary election rivals like Josh Mandel, Mike Gibbons, and Jane Timken, each of whom has been touting themselves as pro-Trump candidates.
"I think Trump was a great president, first of all, so when the facts change, you gotta change your mind," Vance said following a town hall-style event at The Union in downtown Marion.
I'll try to make that case as much as possible to people, but I don't worry that after people lick their wounds a little bit we're all going to be on the same team in November."
Should he capture the GOP nomination on May 3, Vance knows he will have to galvanize the various factions of the party in order to win the November general election.
Following his stop Thursday morning in Marion, Vance was headed to Findlay and then to Huber Heights, according to campaign spokesperson Taylor Van Kirk.
A Vance spokesperson said the "Hillbilly Elegy" author and venture capitalist voted for Trump in 2020 and is a firm supporter of the former president.
In the announcement of the endorsement released on April 15, Trump stated that Vance "is the candidate most qualified and ready to win in November."
"When you realize all of the wrong people are attacking Trump, it makes you realize there's something special about the movement that he leads.

Vance means for Ohio race
The endorsement has disappointed some conservative groups in Ohio that don't view Vance as a "true conservative."
Vance may have said some not so great things about me in the past, but he gets it now, and I have seen that in spades," Trump added.
After surprising many political observers by winning the endorsement of former President Donald J. Trump last week, candidate J.D.
The old adage politics makes strange bedfellows seems applicable in the Ohio Republican Party primary election for U.S. Senate.
State Sen. Matt Dolan from the Cleveland area is the lone Republican candidate who hasn't actively courted Trump's endorsement.
For the Republican Party, this (primary election) is kind of the intramural fight, but then the real fight happens in November.
Akron-based We the People Convention President Tom Zawistowski said his group was "stunned" by Trump's endorsement of Vance.
"It's been a tough primary and I think you just gotta do the work trying to persuade people that they should be behind you.
"I didn't think he was going to be a good president, but I was happy to be proven wrong, so that's a big part of it.
Trump Jr. told the crowd he was "proud to join my father in supporting my friend and America First champion J.D.
Donald Trump Jr. joined Vance on "The No BS Tour" on Wednesday evening in Independence, a suburb of Cleveland.
On Saturday, Vance is scheduled to join Trump in what's expected to be a massive rally in Delaware County.
Vance is continuing what he's calling "The No BS Tour" to try to capitalize on Trump's support.

"He is our best chance for victory in what could be a very tough race.
